modules.title: Why Wireless Security Feels Like Herding Invisible Cats

pages.title: Wireless threat model: signals don’t respect walls

content_blocks.text:
Wireless networks broadcast.
- Coverage extends beyond the physical space you control.
- Anyone in range can try to observe, interfere, or impersonate.
- Many commercial wireless paths (especially cellular) are operated by third parties, so treat them like an external/untrusted network path.

Trap: “We’re inside the building, so it’s safe.”
Radio laughs at your building boundaries. Assume attackers can sit outside and still reach your SSID or Bluetooth devices.

Example: A corporate SSID is reachable from the parking lot. Even with strong encryption, attackers can still attempt deauth attacks, evil twin lures, and brute-force attempts (depending on your WPA mode).

checks.prompt: Why should most cellular traffic be treated as if it traverses an untrusted path?
options: The carrier operates the infrastructure outside your control
checks.explanation: The security boundary is control: carriers run the network, so treat it like external transit.

checks.prompt: Which factors make wireless networks harder to secure than wired? (Choose TWO.)
options: Radio can be monitored without physical access to a cable
Wireless always blocks attackers with distance
checks.explanation: The hard part is exposure: anyone in range can listen/attack, and coverage reaches beyond your walls.

pages.title: Connection methods you’ll see on the exam

content_blocks.text:
Common wireless connectivity types and what to remember:
- Wi‑Fi (802.11): local networking, multiple bands/channels, needs strong auth+encryption.
- Cellular: WAN-like path operated by a carrier.
- Bluetooth: short-range, low power; pairing and profile security matter.
- RFID/NFC: tags/badges/payments; cloning/spoofing risks.
- GPS: broadcast navigation signals; jamming/spoofing risks.
- Infrared: line-of-sight; niche but still shows up.

Quick mental map (range vs typical use):
Infrared: very short + line-of-sight (remotes)
NFC: centimeters (tap-to-pay)
Bluetooth: meters (peripherals)
Wi‑Fi: tens of meters+ (LAN)
Cellular: kilometers (WAN)
RFID: varies (cm to many meters, depending on tag/reader)
GPS: global receive (satellite broadcast)

checks.prompt: NFC is MOST associated with:
checks.explanation: NFC is built for very short range (tap-to-pay, badges).

checks.prompt: Match the technology to the best description.
checks.explanation: These pairings are the exam-friendly defaults.

pages.title: Bands and standards: the exam-safe highlights

content_blocks.text:
Wi‑Fi runs mainly in 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands, with 6 GHz added for Wi‑Fi 6E/7.
Standards you should recognize:
- 802.11b/g: 2.4 GHz legacy.
- 802.11a/ac: 5 GHz legacy/modern.
- 802.11n (Wi‑Fi 4): 2.4 + 5.
- 802.11ax (Wi‑Fi 6/6E): 2.4 + 5 + 6.
- 802.11be (Wi‑Fi 7): 2.4 + 5 + 6 (very high throughput).

Trap: “Higher frequency always means longer range.”
Higher frequencies generally suffer more attenuation (walls/obstacles), so 2.4 GHz often reaches farther than 5/6 GHz.

checks.prompt: Which band is MOST associated with Wi‑Fi 6E expansion?
checks.explanation: Wi‑Fi 6E is the 6 GHz addition to Wi‑Fi 6 (802.11ax).

checks.prompt: Which is a true statement about 2.4 GHz vs 5/6 GHz?
options: 2.4 GHz usually has more range but more interference
5 GHz always travels farther than 2.4 GHz
checks.explanation: 2.4 GHz often reaches farther but is crowded; 5/6 GHz tends to be faster with more channels but shorter range.

pages.title: Infrastructure vs ad hoc, and why it matters

content_blocks.text:
Wi‑Fi deployment modes:
- Infrastructure mode: clients talk through an access point (AP). This is the enterprise norm.
- Ad hoc mode: devices talk directly to each other (peer-to-peer). This can bypass enterprise controls if unmanaged.
SSID basics:
- SSID is the Wi‑Fi network name.
- SSIDs can be broadcast or “hidden,” but hiding is not strong security.
Example: A laptop creates an ad hoc network (or phone hotspot). That can become a bridge between a secured corporate segment and an insecure network if the device also has wired access.

Trap: “Hidden SSID = secure.”
Hidden SSIDs can still be discovered. Real security comes from WPA2/WPA3, strong authentication, and good monitoring.

checks.prompt: In infrastructure mode, client devices communicate primarily:
checks.explanation: Infrastructure mode is AP-centric.

checks.prompt: What is the best description of an SSID?
checks.explanation: SSID is the network identifier/name.

content_blocks.text:
Two look-alike threats:
- Rogue AP: an unauthorized access point connected to or near your environment (may be accidental or malicious).
- Evil twin: a malicious AP that *imitates* a trusted SSID to lure clients.
Both are solved with detection + response, but the intent differs.

Mental picture:
Rogue AP = “an extra door you didn’t approve.”
Evil twin = “a fake door with your company logo painted on it.”

Trap: “Any unknown AP is an evil twin.”
Evil twins specifically imitate your SSID/brand to capture clients; rogue APs are simply unauthorized.

checks.prompt: Which best describes an evil twin?
options: Unauthorized AP on your wired network
Malicious AP imitating a trusted SSID to lure clients
checks.explanation: Evil twins are impersonators built to trick clients.

checks.prompt: Which best describes a rogue access point?
options: Only an AP that spoofs your SSID
checks.explanation: Rogue APs are unauthorized, regardless of whether they imitate an SSID.

content_blocks.text:
Common enterprise approach:
- Perform wireless scans to discover SSIDs/BSSIDs and signal strength patterns.
- Correlate with wired network data to see whether an AP is actually connected to your infrastructure.
- Use containment carefully (legal/policy constraints) and remove unauthorized devices physically when possible.

Example: You see a suspicious SSID near the office. If it’s not plugged into your switches, it might be a neighbor’s Wi‑Fi or a personal hotspot. If it is plugged in, it’s a true rogue AP risk to your network.

checks.prompt: What is a practical way to determine whether a discovered AP is truly on your corporate network?
options: Correlate wireless discovery with wired network logs/traffic
Increase transmit power on all APs
checks.explanation: You need to prove it has a wired uplink into your environment.

checks.prompt: Fill in the blank: An evil twin’s main goal is to ______ clients into connecting to a malicious access point.
checks.explanation: Evil twins impersonate trusted networks to lure clients.

modules.title: Kicking Clients Off Wi‑Fi: Deauth vs Jamming

content_blocks.text:
Deauthentication/disassociation attacks send spoofed management frames that tell clients to disconnect.
Why attackers do it:
- Create a reconnection window to lure users to an evil twin.
- Cause disruption (availability impact).

Trap: “If users disconnect, it must be RF interference.”
A deauth attack can look like ‘random drops’ but it’s protocol-level, not spectrum noise.

checks.prompt: A deauthentication attack primarily uses:
options: Spoofed Wi‑Fi management frames to disconnect clients
IP spoofing to hijack TCP sessions
checks.explanation: Deauth is a management-frame attack.

checks.prompt: Why do deauth attacks often pair well with an evil twin?
options: They force clients to choose a new SSID
They encourage clients to reconnect, allowing the attacker to present a stronger fake AP
checks.explanation: Deauth creates a reconnection moment the attacker can exploit.

content_blocks.text:
Jamming is RF interference: overwhelming a frequency band so devices can’t communicate.
Key properties:
- Can be malicious or accidental (crowded spectrum).
- Encryption doesn’t help—if the radio can’t talk, security features are irrelevant.
Example: A warehouse adds new 2.4 GHz devices, causing intermittent Wi‑Fi drops. That can look like ‘jamming’ but may be accidental interference.

Trap: “WPA3 stops jamming.”
WPA3 strengthens authentication and protects some frames, but it can’t stop RF interference.

checks.prompt: Jamming is best described as:
checks.explanation: Jamming is spectrum-level interference.

checks.prompt: Which control MOST directly helps against deauth attacks (not jamming)?
checks.explanation: PMF protects management frames against spoofing.

content_blocks.text:
Bluetooth is short-range and low-power, but it’s still a network.
Exam-level focus:
- Pairing establishes trust between devices.
- Security modes and profiles determine what access is allowed.
- Leaving Bluetooth on when not needed increases attack surface.

Trap: “Bluetooth range is tiny so it’s safe.”
Range depends on class and environment. Also, attackers can get close in public spaces.

checks.prompt: Bluetooth is MOST commonly used for:
options: Inventory tags readable from hundreds of meters
checks.explanation: Bluetooth is built for short-range peripherals and device links.

checks.prompt: A basic hardening step for Bluetooth on mobile devices is to:
options: Disable Bluetooth when not in use
checks.explanation: Reducing exposure lowers attack surface.

content_blocks.text:
Bluetooth attacks you should differentiate:
- Bluejacking: unsolicited messages (spam/annoyance).
- Bluesnarfing: unauthorized access to device data (contacts/files).
- Impersonation/BIAs: protocol weaknesses used to impersonate devices or bypass authentication assumptions.

Trap: “They’re all just Bluetooth spam.”
Bluesnarfing is the data-theft one—treat it like a confidentiality breach.

checks.prompt: Which Bluetooth attack is most associated with unauthorized access to device data?
checks.explanation: Bluesnarfing targets data theft.

checks.prompt: Bluetooth impersonation attacks are primarily about:
checks.explanation: Impersonation attacks exploit protocol and auth design weaknesses.

modules.title: Designing Wi‑Fi That Doesn’t Hate You: Surveys, Heat Maps, Channels

content_blocks.text:
Wireless design starts with knowing your RF environment.
- Site surveys identify existing signals, obstacles, and coverage needs.
- Heat maps visualize where signal is strong/weak.
- Tools: Wi‑Fi analyzers help capture channel use, signal strength, and noise.
Example: A call center has dead zones near elevators (metal + interference). A survey/heat map guides AP placement and power tuning.

checks.prompt: The primary purpose of a wireless site survey is to:
options: Plan AP placement and channel use based on the RF environment
checks.explanation: Surveys provide the data needed to design coverage/performance.

checks.prompt: A wireless heat map is mainly used to visualize:
options: Signal strength and coverage across a space
checks.explanation: Heat maps show RF coverage patterns.

content_blocks.text:
Channel planning reduces interference.
2.4 GHz is crowded and channels overlap, so the classic non-overlapping set is 1 / 6 / 11.
5/6 GHz usually has more channels and less overlap pressure, but shorter range and more attenuation through walls.

Trap: “Pick any channels; the controller will fix it.”
Controllers can help, but bad physical placement and poor initial design still hurt availability and user experience.

checks.prompt: In many regions, the commonly used non-overlapping 2.4 GHz channel set is:
checks.explanation: 1/6/11 is the classic channel plan to reduce overlap.

checks.prompt: Which statements are generally true? (Choose TWO.)
options: 2.4 GHz tends to have more interference
6 GHz always has longer range than 2.4 GHz
Channel planning is irrelevant if you use WPA3
checks.explanation: Bands affect interference and channel availability; WPA mode doesn’t solve RF engineering problems.

modules.title: Hardening Wireless Infrastructure: Controllers and APs

content_blocks.text:
Treat controllers/APs like critical network infrastructure:
- Change default credentials; enforce strong admin auth.
- Patch firmware and disable unnecessary services.
- Isolate management interfaces (dedicated management network/VLAN).
- Enable logging/monitoring; protect configuration backups.

Trap: “APs are just radios.”
Modern APs are computers: OS, services, management interfaces—so they get attacked like computers.

checks.prompt: Which is a best practice for securing a WLAN controller?
options: Place admin interfaces on isolated management networks and patch regularly
Enable legacy insecure protocols for compatibility
checks.explanation: Segmentation + patching + hardening are key.

checks.prompt: Which actions improve AP security? (Choose TWO.)
options: Protect admin access on a management VLAN
Hide SSID as the primary control
checks.explanation: Hardening and management isolation matter; SSID hiding is not a strong security control.

modules.title: WPA2: Personal vs Enterprise, and Why CCMP Matters

content_blocks.text:
WPA2 security models:
- WPA2‑Personal: PSK (shared passphrase). Simple, but weak accountability.
- WPA2‑Enterprise: 802.1X + RADIUS + EAP. Stronger identity, per-user control, better auditability.
Rule of thumb: if you care about *who* did what, Enterprise beats PSK.

Trap: “PSK gives per-user accountability.”
A shared secret is shared blame. Enterprise auth is the per-user/per-device model.

checks.prompt: WPA2‑Personal is MOST accurately described as:
options: A preshared key model without an auth server
Client certificates required for every device
checks.explanation: WPA2‑Personal uses a shared PSK.

checks.prompt: WPA2‑Enterprise relies on:
checks.explanation: Enterprise mode is 802.1X with RADIUS and EAP methods.

content_blocks.text:
WPA2 commonly uses CCMP with AES for strong Wi‑Fi frame protection.
Exam-level takeaway:
- CCMP/AES is the stronger modern choice.
- Legacy mechanisms (like TKIP/WEP-era crypto) are not acceptable for modern security needs.

Trap: “Captive portal = encryption.”
Portals are access control; CCMP/AES is link-layer encryption.

checks.prompt: CCMP in WPA2 primarily provides:
checks.explanation: CCMP is the AES-based protection mechanism for Wi‑Fi frames.

checks.prompt: Fill in the blank: WPA2 commonly uses ______ with AES for encryption and frame protection.
checks.explanation: CCMP (Counter Mode with CBC-MAC Protocol) is the classic WPA2 choice.

modules.title: WPA3 and Enhanced Open: What Actually Improved

content_blocks.text:
WPA3‑Personal upgrades WPA2‑PSK by using SAE (Simultaneous Authentication of Equals).
Key benefits:
- Harder offline guessing vs classic PSK captures.
- Can support perfect forward secrecy (PFS) so past sessions stay safe even if the password leaks later.
- Requires protected management frames (PMF) to reduce spoofed deauth attacks.

Trap: “WPA3 is just ‘bigger AES’.”
The real win is improved authentication (SAE) and management frame protection, not just ‘stronger encryption.’

checks.prompt: WPA3‑Personal replaces WPA2‑PSK authentication with:
checks.explanation: SAE is the WPA3‑Personal authentication mechanism.

checks.prompt: Which WPA3 feature most directly helps prevent spoofed deauthentication attacks?
checks.explanation: PMF protects management frames like deauth/disassoc.

content_blocks.text:
WPA3‑Enterprise can operate in a higher security mode (often described as 192‑bit security) and improves key management/frame protection.
Enhanced Open uses OWE (Opportunistic Wireless Encryption):
- It adds encryption to ‘open’ networks when possible.
- It does not provide user authentication by itself (so it’s not the same as Enterprise auth).
Example: A coffee shop wants privacy against passive sniffing but doesn’t want user accounts. Enhanced Open (OWE) can encrypt sessions without passwords.

Trap: “OWE = secure identity.”
OWE provides encryption, not identity. For user identity and accountability, you need 802.1X/RADIUS/EAP.

checks.prompt: Enhanced Open primarily uses which technique?
checks.explanation: Enhanced Open is OWE-based.

checks.prompt: Which statement is most accurate about OWE?
options: It provides encryption on otherwise open networks
checks.explanation: OWE adds encryption but not user identity.

modules.title: Wireless Authentication Choices: Open, Captive Portal, PSK, 802.1X

pages.title: Captive portals: access control, not encryption

content_blocks.text:
Captive portals redirect users to a web page (terms, login, voucher) before granting access.
Important: portals do not automatically encrypt Wi‑Fi traffic. Without WPA2/WPA3 (or OWE), the link layer remains exposed.

Trap: “Captive portal = secure Wi‑Fi.”
A portal is a gate, not armor. Use WPA2/WPA3 (or OWE for open) for encryption.

checks.prompt: A captive portal is most commonly used to:
options: Redirect users to a registration/terms page before granting access
checks.explanation: Portals gate access via web-based interaction.

checks.prompt: The biggest weakness of a truly open network with a captive portal is:
options: Traffic is not encrypted at the Wi‑Fi layer
checks.explanation: Captive portals don't encrypt the Wi‑Fi link.

content_blocks.text:
802.1X high-level flow:
Client (supplicant) ⇄ AP (authenticator) ⇄ RADIUS (authentication server)
EAP is carried between client and RADIUS (often inside a TLS tunnel depending on method).

Why this is strong:
- Per-user or per-device credentials.
- Policy decisions (who can join which VLAN/role).
- Central logging and revocation (disable one user without changing a shared PSK).

checks.prompt: 802.1X is best described as:
options: Port-based access control standard used on wired and wireless networks
checks.explanation: 802.1X is access control, not an encryption algorithm.

checks.prompt: Fill in the blank: In enterprise Wi‑Fi, EAP is commonly used inside ______ authentication.
checks.explanation: EAP methods operate within 802.1X access control.

modules.title: EAP Method Matrix: PEAP vs EAP‑TLS vs TTLS vs FAST

content_blocks.text:
EAP methods differ a lot in certificate requirements:
- EAP‑TLS: mutual cert auth (client + server certificates). Strong but certificate-heavy.
- PEAP: server certificate + TLS tunnel; inner authentication happens inside the tunnel.
- EAP‑TTLS: TLS tunnel and can often avoid client certs.
- EAP‑FAST: designed to speed (re)authentication, useful for roaming scenarios.

Trap: “All EAP methods require client certificates.”
Only EAP‑TLS *requires* client certs as a core feature.

checks.prompt: Which EAP method requires client certificates as a standard expectation?
checks.explanation: EAP‑TLS is the mutual certificate method.

checks.prompt: Match each EAP method to its hallmark.
right: TLS tunnel often without client certs

correct_map.EAP‑TTLS: TLS tunnel often without client certs

checks.explanation: This is a common exam matching set.

content_blocks.text:
RADIUS federation extends trust across organizations.
Use-case:
- A university, vendor, or partner user authenticates using their home credentials, and your network accepts it through a federated trust path.
Security angle:
- Still gives identity + centralized policy, without sharing one PSK across orgs.

Trap: “Federation means we share passwords.”
Federation is about trust and validation between authentication systems—not copying secrets around.

checks.prompt: RADIUS federation primarily enables:
options: Partner users to authenticate using their home credentials through a trust relationship
checks.explanation: Federation allows cross-organization authentication with trust.

checks.prompt: Fill in the blank: WPA2/WPA3 Enterprise typically uses 802.1X with an authentication server such as ______.
checks.explanation: RADIUS is the classic backend for enterprise Wi‑Fi authentication.

modules.title: Mobile Deployment Models: BYOD, CYOD, COPE, COBO

content_blocks.text:
Mobile deployment models (think: who owns it, who controls it?):
- BYOD: user-owned; org has limited control; highest risk.
- CYOD: org-owned but user picks from approved options; better standardization.
- COPE: corporate-owned, personally enabled; org-managed with allowed personal use.
- COBO: corporate-owned, business-only; maximum control, minimal personal flexibility.

Trap: “BYOD is fine because users care about their phones.”
Users optimize for convenience, not your risk appetite. BYOD needs strong policy + technical controls.

checks.prompt: In BYOD, which statement is most accurate?
options: Org owns and maintains the device
User owns and controls the device, reducing org oversight
BYOD guarantees stronger security than corporate-owned
checks.explanation: BYOD reduces organizational control and increases risk.

checks.prompt: COPE is best described as:
options: Org-owned and managed device that allows personal use
checks.explanation: COPE = corporate-owned, personally enabled.

pages.title: Picking the right model in real life

content_blocks.text:
Examples:
- BYOD: contractors accessing email/SSO on personal phones.
- CYOD: corporate program where employees choose from a short list (easier patching/support).
- COBO: warehouse scanners, kiosks, clinical devices with strict requirements.

Exam heuristic:
More corporate ownership → more enforceable security.
More personal ownership → more policy/MDM compromise and legal/privacy constraints.

checks.prompt: CYOD most commonly means:
options: User buys any device and org manages it fully
Org owns device but user chooses from approved options
Org forbids personal use on all devices
Devices are unmanaged and used only for Wi‑Fi
checks.explanation: CYOD is organization-owned with user choice among approved models.

checks.prompt: COBO deployments are most appropriate when:
options: The device is for a single business purpose and personal use is not allowed
Users must pick among many personal brands
Device must join open Wi‑Fi only
checks.explanation: COBO = business-only, high control.

modules.title: MDM/UEM: Controls That Still Work When Users (and Thieves) Try Weird Stuff

content_blocks.text:
MDM (Mobile Device Management) and UEM (Unified Endpoint Management) enforce security policy on endpoints.
Common capabilities:
- App management (install/remove/allow/block)
- Content management (protect corporate documents/media)
- Configuration enforcement (screen lock, biometrics, encryption)
- Remote wipe (full wipe) vs ‘wipe only org data’ (selective/corporate wipe)
- OTA updates/patch enforcement and compliance reporting
Example: BYOD email access where the org can wipe corporate email/app data without deleting personal photos.

Trap: “Remote wipe always saves you.”
Wipe requires connectivity. Attackers often isolate stolen devices immediately.

checks.prompt: Which are common MDM/UEM capabilities? (Choose THREE.)
checks.explanation: MDM/UEM manages endpoint policy; RF channel overlap is Wi‑Fi engineering, not endpoint management.

checks.prompt: Why can remote wipe fail in a theft scenario?
options: It requires connectivity and attackers can isolate devices
checks.explanation: Remote wipe depends on reaching the device.

pages.title: Hardening controls: the boring stuff that wins

content_blocks.text:
Hardening techniques commonly highlighted:
- Keep OS and apps patched (use OTA updates).
- Require passcodes, strong screen locks, and wipe-after-failure policies.
- Enable full-device encryption (FDE) to protect data at rest.
- Turn off radios (Bluetooth/NFC) when not needed.
- Use CIS Benchmarks as a hardening baseline for iOS/Android.

Trap: “Biometrics replace passcodes.”
Biometrics are great, but still backstop with a strong passcode policy and lock settings.

checks.prompt: Which control provides the strongest baseline protection for data at rest if a phone is stolen?
checks.explanation: Encryption protects offline data even if the device is isolated.

checks.prompt: CIS Benchmarks are primarily used to:
options: Provide secure configuration baselines for systems like iOS and Android
checks.explanation: They are hardening baselines.

content_blocks.text:
Location features show up twice: security and privacy.
- Geolocation: determining where a device is.
- Geofencing: applying policy when inside/outside a boundary.
- GPS tagging for photos/documents can leak sensitive location info; MDM/UEM may restrict it.
Also common mobile risks:
- Sideloading and jailbreaking increase risk by bypassing platform controls.

Trap: “Geolocation and geofencing are the same.”
Geolocation answers ‘where is it?’; geofencing answers ‘what policy triggers because of where it is?’

checks.prompt: Geofencing is best described as:
options: Applying rules based on device being inside/outside a defined boundary
checks.explanation: Geofencing is location-based policy enforcement.

checks.prompt: Why do organizations sometimes disable GPS tagging for photos/documents?
checks.explanation: GPS metadata can expose sensitive locations.

modules.title: Mobile Platform Risks: Sideloading and Jailbreaking

content_blocks.text:
Sideloading: installing apps from outside the official app store.
- Risk: bypasses vetting and can violate org policy.
Jailbreaking/rooting: privilege escalation to gain elevated OS control.
- Risk: breaks security model, enables deeper tampering and persistence.

Trap: “Sideloading = jailbreaking.”
Sideloading is a distribution path; jailbreaking is privilege escalation. They overlap, but they’re not identical.

checks.prompt: Sideloading means:
options: Installing only from the official store
Installing apps from outside the official store
checks.explanation: Sideloading is installing outside official channels.

checks.prompt: Jailbreaking most closely resembles:
options: Privilege escalation to gain root/admin control
checks.explanation: Jailbreaking is privilege escalation.

content_blocks.text:
Controls commonly used to reduce these risks:
- Allow/deny lists for apps; restrict unknown sources.
- Compliance checks: detect rooted/jailbroken devices and quarantine access.
- Patch enforcement (OTA updates) to reduce exploitability.
- Containerization to limit blast radius if personal side is compromised.
Example: If a phone is detected as jailbroken, MDM can block corporate email, revoke certificates, and require remediation before re-enabling access.

checks.prompt: Which controls help reduce sideloading/jailbreaking risk? (Choose TWO.)
checks.explanation: Endpoint policy and patching reduce risk; RF choices don’t fix OS privilege problems.

checks.prompt: Fill in the blank: Jailbreaking typically weakens the mobile OS security model by granting ______ privileges.
checks.explanation: Root/admin privileges allow bypassing many built-in security controls.
